title: 103_hr1282
content: The Act is titled the "Outer Continental Shelf Enhanced Exploration and Deep Water Incentives Act" and includes amendments to the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act. The Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act is amended to allow the Secretary to reduce, suspend, or eliminate royalties or net profit shares to promote development and production on leases. Lessees can petition for this incentive, with a final decision made within 6 months. The Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act allows the Secretary to reduce royalties on new production from leases in water depths of 200 meters or greater until capital costs are recovered. Royalties apply if oil prices exceed $28 per barrel or natural gas prices exceed $3.50. The Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act allows the Secretary to reduce royalties on new production from leases in water depths of 200 meters or greater until capital costs are recovered. Royalties apply if oil prices exceed $28 per barrel or natural gas prices exceed $3.50. Prices can be adjusted annually based on the consumer price index. No impact on bonus bids. Capital costs defined by the Secretary include exploration and development costs related to new production. The Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act allows the Secretary to reduce royalties on new production from leases in water depths of 200 meters or greater until capital costs are recovered. New production excludes royalties from test production or lease development activities approved by the Secretary. Capital costs are adjusted annually based on the consumer price index. The Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act allows the Secretary to designate frontier areas on the outer Continental Shelf where royalties can be reduced, suspended, or eliminated to account for increased capital costs in exploration and development in coastal or marine environments, including arctic regions. The Secretary will issue regulations within specific timeframes to implement amendments and define "frontier area" for the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act.
